Introduction

This document is the policy and procedure for actions that must be taken in order for Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust to satisfy its' statutory duty with regards to the maintenance and safe operation of passenger and goods lifts (including disabled raising platforms) present on main Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust and satellite collaborative premises (with passenger/goods lift and/or disabled platform provision) under The Trust's responsibility. Application of this policy will aim towards compliance in line with the relevant statutory legislation and guidance as far as is reasonably practicable.

Passenger and goods lifts under Trust control are subject to a maintenance contract with a ‘Specialised Lift Maintenance Contractor' and receive thorough Examination and Test certification by an Competent Person every  or  months intervals dependant on the lift and the duty it has, or in accordance with a written scheme of examination. Servicing is completed monthly to all lifts due to the importance of these to the service. Improvements identified through inspections are undertaken and any defects repaired as required.

The trust appoints the specialist maintenance contractor as well as the specialist insurance contractors who are also the competent persons (appointed by the Duty holder) to ensure a safe system of work is in place for the protection of staff, patients, members of the public and visitors who have the potential to be affected by their actions.
The Specialised Lift Maintenance Contractor's safe systems of work includes but is not limited to the following:
use of barriers at lift landings when the doors are open to the shaft,
warning signs when lifts are out of use and the protection of tools and equipment from unauthorised access.
carryout periodic monitoring to check that they appear to be working safely including use of props or other safety devices when working beneath the lift car

working at height controls this includes a permit to work for contractors and working at height permits. Southend site have a standard long term permit to work , this being based on a full suite of generic risk assessments supplied by the contractor that cover all reactive and maintenance duties that will be encountered undertaking lift maintenance , which includes working at height with hazardous substances and / or confined spaces to provide a safe system
of work
The Trust ensures that:
lift cars clearly display safe working loads and the maximum number of passengers
when building works take place, that the lift is not used inappropriately and that safe load limits are adhered to.
lift cars are also equipped with a passenger alarm/emergency telephone.

lift entrapment procedures are in place involving telephone connection directly between the lift car and the hospital switchboard. This call must be answered within 5 minutes. The Call centre or switchboard must be manned 24/7 and anyone trapped must be able to talk directly to a person not an answer phone or an automated call as per HTM  .02 9.12-13-14:
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:

Detail the measures that will be in place within the Trust and within Estates and Facilities  Management  who  have  responsibility  in  terms  of  inspection, maintenance of the lifts and release of those who become entrapped within.
Definitions

table_items.text: Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust
These are lifts which are used within the Trust by staff, contractors, members of public, visitors etc.
These are lifts which are designed and may only be used for transporting goods between different levels with the Trusts buildings e.g. Medical Notes, theatre equipment BUT not used to carry people
When the passenger lift fails to operate correctly trapping people within the lift car
Systematic and detailed examination of the lift and all its

associated equipment by a competent person. Its aim is to detect any defects which are, or might become, dangerous, and for the competent person to report them to the duty holder (Trust) so that appropriate remedial action can be taken. To determine the extent of the thorough examination, the competent person will assess the risks, considering factors such as where the lift will be used, frequency of use, age and condition, the weight of loads to be lifted, etc.
The term 'competent person' is not defined in law but the LOLER Approved Code of Practice and guidance states that:

Trust ‘Should ensure that the person undertaking thorough examination has such appropriate practical and theoretical knowledge and experience of the lifting equipment to be thoroughly examined, as will enable them to detect defects or weaknesses and to assess their importance in relation to the safety and continued use of the lifting equipment.'

A safe system of work is a formal procedure which results from systematic examination of a task in order to identify all the hazards. It defines safe methods to ensure that hazards are eliminated or risks minimised.

Examination and inspection (legislative requirements)

In order to verify that lifting equipment and accessories remain safe for use, and to detect and remedy any deterioration in good time, thorough examinations are required throughout the lifetime of the lifting equipment, including examinations:

Before use for the first time - unless the equipment has an CCE or UKCA Declaration of Conformity less than one year old and the equipment was not assembled on site. If it was assembled on site, it must be examined by a competent person to ensure that the assembly (eg a platform lift installed in a building) was completed correctly and safely

Regularly, while in service - Most lifting equipment will be subject to wear and tear and so will need regular in-service examination. Unless there is an 'examination scheme' specifying other intervals, thorough examinations should be conducted:
Examination and Inspection – Trust arrangements

It is the responsibility of the Duty Holder to ensure that thorough examinations of lifts are carried out at statutory intervals by the Competent Person (Insurance Engineer). The inspection will result in a certificate of thorough examination which will be issued to the Duty Holder as soon as is practical after the examination has taken place.
The Certificate of Thorough Examination will highlight all the defects found in three categories of varying severity, in most cases A – C Defects (Example of which is shown on Appendix 1).
Lifts with ‘A' defects will be taken out of service immediately by the Dutyholder until the defect is rectified by the Competent Person (Specialised Lift Maintenance Contractor).
Lifts with ‘B' defects will have defects repaired as soon as is reasonably practicable, prior to the next inspection or time waited.
Lifts with ‘C' defects are observations which are recommendations from the
Competent Person.

If lifts are not available for inspection at the time the Competent Person (Service Engineer) attends site, providing the current Certificate of Thorough Examination is still valid the lift can be continued to be used. If expired the lift will be taken out of service with immediate effect until a new examination can be carried out.
Taking Lifts Out of Service

Action following notification of defects - The competent person is legally required to notify Trust (via Authorised Person) as soon as possible, following a thorough examination, of any defects which are, or could soon become, dangerous. If an immediate danger to persons is indicated the lift should be immediately taken out of service until the fault has been addressed. Failure to take lift out of service will result in a legislative breach.

The competent person (Service Engineer) may also notify Trust of defects which need to be made good within a stipulated timescale. In this case, steps to have the defective equipment repaired or replaced within the specified time, and not use the lift after that time unless the defect has been satisfactorily remedied.
Additionally there are various reasons a lift or disable lifting platform may be taken out of service, below are a generic list which is not exhaustive:
Certificate of Thorough Examination expired
Certificate of Thorough Examination has highlighted a defect
Fault with the operation

After a lift entrapment where the fault must not be reset or the lift to go back into service without the Competent person (specialist service provider ) attending site and checking for and rectifying any faults prior to reinstatement .
Fault highlighted through inspection by Lift Steward which poses a risk of injury or harm

In all cases the lift will be electrically isolated by the Authorised Person (Electrical) or Competetnt Person, until the shortfalls have been addressed by the Competent Person (Specialised Lift Maintenance Contractor).
The lift should be electrically isolated by the authorised person (Low voltage Electrical ) or a deputy (being EFM electrical engineer who is site assigned to Competent person level)
Maintenance

All maintenance actions required to be carried out on the lifts will be recorded in the Estates and Facilities Computer Aided Facilities Maintenance system and the individual lift's, log book, located in the lift motor control panel or plant room.
All maintenance except for simple daily checks to the lifts normal operation will be carried out by a Competent Person (Service Engineer) with no exceptions.
Lift Entrapment

In the case that person(s) become trapped in a lift they will use one of the emergency call points within the lift to raise the alarm. This call point is a two way communication between the lift car and the Trust's Telephone Room. The telephone room summons the Lift Release Wardens accordingly. Appendix 2 shows the flowchart of this procedure. In the case that Lift Release Wardens are not available the Fire Service are summoned.
Record Retention

All maintenance records, Certificates of Thorough Examination, records of taking lifts out of service, and training records will be retained for a period of 6 years. The Initial thorough examination report should be kept for the life of the machinary
Training requirements
All staff who have operational duties within this policy will be trained accordingly to carryout their roles; refresher training will need to be carried out on an annual basis.

Appendix 1: Thorough examination
Legislation requires the ‘thorough examination' report must contain certain information, specified in Schedule 1 of LOLER. In summary, it should:
identify the equipment examined (serial number, make, etc), the employer and the premises;
give the date of the last thorough examination and specify when the next one should take place;
specify the safe working load of the lift;
give the reason for the thorough examination (ie following installation, according to an examination scheme, statutory interval, etc);
identify any defect which is or may become a danger to people;

give the details of any repair, renewal or alteration required to remedy the defect and the date by which it should be undertaken; give details of any tests carried out; give details of the person carrying out the report and the person validating the report on their behalf.

If the report does not contain all the information above, Designated Person should not accept it, as this may place you in breach of the law. In this event resolve the matter with the competent person, but if this is unsuccessful you should contact your local enforcing authority for advice.

Thorough examination should not be confused with preventive maintenance, although they have some elements in common. Preventive maintenance usually involves replacing worn or damaged parts, topping up fluid levels and making routine adjustments to ensure risks are avoided. Thorough examination may act
as a check that maintenance is being carried out properly, but is not intended to replace it. Thorough examination should include the following:
landing and car doors and their interlocks;
worm and other gearing;
main drive system components;
governors;
safety gear;
suspension ropes;
suspension chains;
overload detection devices;
electrical devices (including earthing, earth bonding, safety devices, selection of fuses, etc);
braking systems (including buffers and overspeed devices); and
hydraulics.
This list is not exhaustive. More detailed guidance can be found in the Safety Assessment Federation's (SAFed) Lift guidelines (see Further information).
